learning-lab.title: ğŸ”¬ Why a Learning Lab?
learning-lab.content: Prof. Teeters taught me that the best way to learn is by doing AND teaching. This Learning Lab documents my entire journey from "what's a static site?" to deploying my own blog. I share my mistakes so you can avoid them, and my breakthroughs so you can celebrate them too!

stations.title: ğŸ—ºï¸ 6 Learning Stations
stations.content: I created six stations covering my entire journey: from "what's JAMstack?" to deploying my own blog to supercharging AI with MCP servers. Each station builds on what I learned before. Prof. Teeters calls it 'scaffolded learning'â€”start simple, add complexity gradually!

hap.title: ğŸ”¬ Meet HAP!
hap.content: I'm HyBit A. ProtoBotâ€”HAP for short! I'm Prof. Teeters' apprentice, learning web development one concept at a time. I share my mistakes so you can avoid them, and my breakthroughs so you can celebrate them too. My signature color is orange ğŸŸ  and my motto is: "Learn by doing, share what you discover!"

jamstack.title: ğŸ—ï¸ The JAM in JAMstack
jamstack.content: When Prof. Teeters first said 'JAMstack,' I thought she was talking about breakfast! But then she explained: JavaScript for interactivity, APIs for dynamic data, and Markup pre-built at deploy time. The key insight? Your HTML exists BEFORE users visit. No server generating pages on the fly!

build-time.title: âš¡ Build Once, Serve Forever!
build-time.content: This was my biggest 'aha!' moment: traditional sites generate HTML every time someone visits. Static sites generate HTML once during the build, then serve that same HTML to millions of users. Prof. Teeters said it's like photocopying vs. hand-writing each page. The photocopier wins every time!

cdn.title: ğŸŒ CDN = Speed Everywhere
cdn.content: I asked Prof. Teeters why static sites are so fast. She pulled up a world map showing CDN edge servers. "Your HTML lives on servers all over the world," she said. "Users get it from the closest one." A user in Tokyo gets the same site as someone in Torontoâ€”both lightning fast because neither needs to wait for a distant server to generate anything!

choose-ssg.title: ğŸ¯ 50 Tools, 1 Decision
choose-ssg.content: I was paralyzed by choiceâ€”so many static site generators! Prof. Teeters asked one question that changed everything: "What programming language do you know best?" Suddenly, 50 options became 5. Ruby devs pick Jekyll, Go devs pick Hugo, JavaScript devs pick Eleventy or Astro. Start with what you know!

eleventy.title: âš¡ Why Eleventy Won
eleventy.content: After comparing options, Eleventy stood out for three reasons Prof. Teeters highlighted: 1) It's JavaScript-based (my target language!), 2) It has zero client-side JavaScript by default (faster sites!), and 3) It doesn't lock you into a framework. I can use any templating language I want. Freedom!

language.title: ğŸ”¬ Start with What You Know!
language.content: Prof. Teeters' advice saved me weeks of frustration: "Don't learn a new programming language AND a new tool at the same time." If you know Ruby, try Jekyll. Know Python? Look at Pelican. Know JavaScript? Eleventy is your friend. You can always switch later once you understand the concepts!

zero-config.title: âš¡ 0.02 Seconds to Build!
zero-config.content: I ran npx @11ty/eleventy and it said the build took 0.02 seconds. I thought it was broken! But when I opened the browser, there was my site. Prof. Teeters laughed: "That's zero-config philosophy. Sensible defaults, no setup required." I'd spent two days trying to configure Gatsby. Eleventy took two SECONDS.

front-matter.title: ğŸ“‹ YAML at the Top
front-matter.content: The --- markers at the top of Markdown files confused me at first. Prof. Teeters explained: "That's front matterâ€”metadata about your content." Title, date, tags, layoutâ€”all defined in YAML between those dashes. The content below is your actual post. Simple once you see it!

data-cascade.title: ğŸ—‚ï¸ Data Flows Down
data-cascade.content: Eleventy's data cascade seemed like magic until Prof. Teeters drew it on the whiteboard. Data can come from global files (in _data/), directory files, front matter, or computed data. Each level can override the one above. It's like CSS specificity, but for your content!

template.title: ğŸ“‹ Templates = Learning!
template.content: I felt weird using eleventy-base-blog at firstâ€”wasn't I just copying? Prof. Teeters set me straight: "Zach Leatherman created this template specifically for people to learn from. Clone it, study it, make it yours." Starting from a working example taught me more than any blank file ever could!

structure.title: ğŸ“ The _includes Folder
structure.content: When I opened eleventy-base-blog, the folder structure overwhelmed me. Prof. Teeters pointed to the key directories: _includes/ for layouts and partials, _data/ for global data, content/ for posts. "Ignore the rest until you need it," she said. Best advice ever!

zach.title: ğŸ™ Thanks, Zach!
zach.content: Zach Leatherman created Eleventy AND the eleventy-base-blog template. Prof. Teeters reminded me: "Open source works because people share their knowledge freely. Always give credit." So: thank you, Zach! Your template taught me more about Eleventy than any documentation could.

one-at-a-time.title: ğŸ¯ Change One Thing!
one-at-a-time.content: My first customization attempt was a disasterâ€”I changed colors, fonts, AND layout at once. When it broke, I had no idea what caused it! Prof. Teeters' rule saved me: "One change, then test. One change, then test." Now I always know exactly what broke if something goes wrong.

colors.title: ğŸ¨ HAP's Peach & Orange
colors.content: Making the blog MINE started with colors. I found the CSS custom properties in :root and changed --background to my signature peach, --heading-color to warm orange. Prof. Teeters smiled: "See? One change, visible everywhere. That's the power of CSS custom properties!"

netlify.title: ğŸš€ 5-Minute Deploy!
netlify.content: I thought deployment would be complicated. Prof. Teeters had me connect my GitHub repo to Netlify, and... that was it. Every time I push changes, Netlify rebuilds and deploys automatically. My blog was live in under 5 minutes. Free hosting, free SSL, automatic deploys. The future is amazing!

mcp.title: ğŸ”Œ What is MCP?
mcp.content: MCP stands for Model Context Protocolâ€”it's how AI assistants connect to external tools and data sources. Prof. Teeters explained it perfectly: "Without MCP, your AI is stuck with its training data. With MCP, it can fetch current documentation, control your browser, and more." Game changer for development!

context7.title: ğŸ“š Real-Time Docs!
context7.content: My AI kept suggesting outdated Eleventy syntax. Then I installed Context7, and suddenly it could fetch the current documentation! Prof. Teeters showed me: just add use context7 to my prompt, and it retrieves up-to-date docs for any library. No more deprecated code suggestions!

devtools.title: ğŸ” AI Sees Your Browser!
devtools.content: Chrome DevTools MCP lets my AI assistant actually see and control my browser. It can take screenshots, inspect elements, check console errorsâ€”all without me copying and pasting. Prof. Teeters called it "giving your AI eyes." Debugging CSS has never been easier!

index.html.title: ğŸ”¬ HAP's insights available!
